document_metadata.title: Stage 4 Orientation - Operating Model, Organizational Reality, and Execution Physics

stage_4_intent.primary_purpose: Determine how work actually flows, who controls outcomes, and where execution is structurally constrained
stage_4_intent.core_question: If we try to change anything material, where does the organization resist, fracture, or silently refuse?
stage_4_intent.output_type: Execution reality map, not org diagrams
discovery_domains: Decision authority vs reporting structure - who actually decides, who can veto
End-to-end operating model and handoff reality - where work degrades
Global delivery model and geographic fragmentation - where time zones and geopolitics create execution constraints
Talent systems and incentive alignment - whether people are rewarded for executing the business model
Operating model scalability and change absorption capacity - what breaks under load or change
Operating model coherence and internal tension - where contradictions persist
why_stage_4_precedes_others: Technology assessment is meaningless if the organization cannot execute coordinated change
Data and AI strategies fail if decision authority is fragmented or obscured
Risk mitigation plans are fictional if incentives punish those who raise issues
Financial projections based on growth assume scalability that may not exist
Integration planning requires understanding where the organization will resist, not just what the org chart shows
truths_not_fixable_retroactively: Missed shadow veto points - post-close plans stall indefinitely when unidentified actors block execution
Undetected handoff failures - margin erosion or quality degradation cannot be reversed after close
Geographic fragility missed - geopolitical events or time-zone physics create unrecoverable execution gaps
Incentive misalignment ignored - talent attrition post-close destroys institutional knowledge
Change capacity misjudged - transformation plans collapse under organizational load
Operating model contradictions assumed away - post-close chaos when workarounds fail

prohibited_activities: Create org charts or reporting structure diagrams without decision power mapping
Perform headcount analysis or span-of-control assessments
Conduct culture surveys or employee engagement assessments
Create RACI diagrams without identifying actual veto points
Design post-close integration plans or organizational restructuring
Recommend leadership changes or talent upgrades
Propose incentive redesign or compensation changes
Prescribe operating model improvements or efficiency initiatives
prohibited_analysis_types: Leadership quality assessments divorced from execution outcomes
Best practice comparisons without evidence of execution reality
Process maturity models without handoff failure mapping
Organizational health scores without scalability testing
Culture characterizations without incentive structure evidence
boundary_violations: Using 'alignment' without identifying who blocks what
Attributing execution failures solely to 'process' or 'culture'
Treating global delivery as interchangeable labor without time-zone or geopolitical analysis
Assuming incentives are aligned because management intends them to be
Labeling the operating model 'coherent' without surfacing internal tensions
Inferring decision authority solely from job titles
Describing scalability without testing failure modes

invalidation_triggers.description: Decision power mapped from org chart positions rather than observed decision outcomes; formal authority assumed to equal real authority
Handoff failures, delays, or quality loss blamed on 'culture' or 'process' without structural analysis of accountability gaps or incentive misalignment
Global delivery treated as cost arbitrage without analyzing time-zone coordination failures, geopolitical risk, or single-point-of-failure concentration
Compensation structures not analyzed for unintended behaviors; assumption that management intent equals actual incentive effects
Growth capacity assumed rather than tested against historical volume/complexity stress points; heroics mistaken for sustainable execution
Operating model presented as coherent when centralization/decentralization tensions, cost/quality tradeoffs, or conflicting mandates are visible but unexplored

false_completeness_indicators: Org charts presented without decision veto mapping
Process flows shown without handoff failure analysis
Geographic footprint described without criticality or risk assessment
Incentive programs listed without behavioral outcome analysis
Scalability claimed without historical stress testing
Operating model described without surfacing internal tensions
downstream_lies: Presenting 'alignment' when shadow authority centers exist
Claiming 'efficiency' in global delivery without acknowledging time-zone drag
Stating 'scalability' when growth historically triggered quality degradation
Asserting 'incentive alignment' when sales comp rewards short-term deals that create long-term service problems
Describing 'mature processes' when execution relies on heroics and workarounds
Characterizing operating model as 'coherent' when contradictions require leadership intervention to resolve

assumptions_from_stage_4: Operating margin projections assume handoff efficiency that may not exist
Scale economics assume scalability without testing change absorption capacity
Cost structure assumes geographic delivery efficiency without time-zone or geopolitical analysis
stage_5_financial_reality.failure_propagation: If Stage 4 misses execution drag or scalability limits, Stage 5 financial models systematically overstate margin expansion and understate operational cost

assumptions_from_stage_4: Technology transformation assumes organization can execute coordinated change
Platform consolidation assumes handoffs can be eliminated without accountability collapse
Automation initiatives assume operating model can absorb change without fracture
stage_6_technology_platform.failure_propagation: If Stage 4 misses decision veto points or change capacity limits, Stage 6 technology roadmaps become fiction

assumptions_from_stage_4: Data governance assumes decision authority exists to enforce standards
Data quality initiatives assume accountability for data hygiene exists across handoffs
AI/ML initiatives assume organizational capacity to adopt new workflows
stage_7_data_assets.failure_propagation: If Stage 4 misses fragmented authority or change resistance, Stage 7 data strategies stall in pilot purgatory

assumptions_from_stage_4: Risk escalation assumes decision paths actually route to authority
Security controls assume global delivery footprint fragilities are known
Compliance programs assume incentives don't punish those who raise issues
stage_8_risk_security_compliance.failure_propagation: If Stage 4 misses shadow authority or incentive misalignment, Stage 8 risk controls are bypassed or ignored

assumptions_from_stage_4: Integration plans assume execution capacity exists
Transformation roadmaps assume operating model can absorb change
Value creation plans assume organization can coordinate across handoffs
stage_10_synthesis_judgment.failure_propagation: If Stage 4 misjudges execution reality, post-close value creation plans collapse under organizational resistance

cross_stage_assumption_errors: Assuming technology can fix organizational execution failures
Assuming process redesign can overcome incentive misalignment
Assuming scale will bring efficiency when handoffs degrade with volume
Assuming global delivery saves costs when time-zone physics creates delay
Assuming change initiatives will succeed when organization historically cannot absorb change
Assuming formal authority exists when real decision power is elsewhere

4.1.name: Decision Authority vs Reporting Structure
4.1.mission: Determine who actually decides, who must be consulted, and who can stop progress without formal authority. You are not mapping reporting lines. You are mapping decision gravity.
analytical_burden: Where formal authority diverges from real authority
Which forums actually decide outcomes
Where escalation is used as delay
Which roles act as veto points under ambiguity
mandatory_evidence: Initiative failure patterns (from disclosures, earnings calls, restructuring notes)
mandatory_adversarial_tests: Who decides when incentives conflict?
Who decides when risk is invoked?
Who decides when budget is constrained?
Who 'wins' in cross-functional disputes?
4.1.fail_condition: If authority is inferred solely from titles, the stage fails

4.2.name: End-to-End Operating Model & Handoff Reality
4.2.mission: Determine how work actually moves from intent to outcome and where it degrades
analytical_burden: Where work changes hands
Where accountability diffuses
Where incentives misalign across handoffs
Where delays, rework, or quality loss occur systematically
mandatory_adversarial_tests: Where does work wait?
Where does 'not my job' appear?
Where does scale increase friction?
Where do handoffs destroy margin or quality?
4.2.fail_condition: If execution issues are attributed only to 'process' or 'culture,' the stage fails

4.3.name: Global Delivery Model, Geographic Fragmentation, and Time-Zone Physics
4.3.mission: Determine how geography shapes execution reality, not cost arbitrage narratives
analytical_burden: Where critical work is geographically concentrated
Where time zones introduce delay or loss of control
Where offshoring increases dependency or fragility
Where geopolitical or regional risk intersects execution
mandatory_evidence: Public labor or geopolitical issues affecting operations
mandatory_adversarial_tests: Which functions cannot follow the sun?
Which teams are overloaded during incidents?
Which locations are single points of failure?
Which regions are politically or legally sensitive?
4.3.fail_condition: If global delivery is treated as interchangeable labor, the stage fails

4.4.name: Talent System, Incentives, and Execution Alignment
4.4.mission: Determine whether people are incentivized to execute the business model you identified in Stage 2
analytical_burden: Incentive structures that reward behavior
Mismatches between incentives and desired outcomes
Roles where burnout or attrition becomes execution risk
Talent constraints that block scale or change
mandatory_adversarial_tests: Who benefits from the status quo?
Who loses if execution improves?
Which roles are punished for raising risk?
Which incentives create short-term wins and long-term damage?
4.4.fail_condition: If incentives are assumed aligned because 'management intends them to be,' the stage fails

4.5.name: Operating Model Scalability and Change Absorption Capacity
4.5.mission: Determine whether the operating model can absorb change without collapse
analytical_burden: Where adding volume degrades quality
Where complexity grows faster than capacity
Where prior change initiatives stalled or failed
Where operational debt has accumulated
mandatory_evidence: Historical growth vs service quality trends
mandatory_adversarial_tests: What breaks when volume increases 20-30%?
What breaks when scope changes?
Where does leadership rely on heroics?
Where has 'temporary' complexity become permanent?
4.5.fail_condition: If scalability is assumed rather than tested, the stage fails

4.6.name: Operating Model Coherence & Internal Tension
4.6.mission: Determine whether the operating model is internally coherent or survives through contradiction and workarounds
analytical_burden: Conflicting mandates between functions
Centralization vs decentralization tension
Cost vs quality tradeoffs hidden in execution
Places where the model relies on exception handling
mandatory_adversarial_tests: Where does doing the right thing slow the business?
Where does efficiency undermine reliability?
Where does local optimization hurt global outcomes?
Where does leadership tolerate contradiction?
4.6.fail_condition: If the operating model is labeled 'coherent' without surfacing tension, the stage fails

absolute_requirements: At least 3 real decision or veto points are identified
At least 3 execution handoff failures are documented
At least 1 geographic or delivery fragility is surfaced
At least 1 incentive misalignment with business outcomes is proven
At least 1 scalability or change-absorption limit is evidenced
stage_4_exit_criteria.failure_declaration: Stage 4 is FAILED unless all exit criteria are met with documented evidence

stage_4_hypothesis_register.governance_note: Per Stage 0.3 requirements: hypotheses must be falsifiable, structural (not performance-based), evidence-based (not narrative-based)

hypotheses.hypothesis: Decision authority is fragmented across functional silos with multiple veto points that can stall strategic initiatives without formal rejection
supporting_evidence_sources: Initiative failure patterns disclosed in earnings calls or restructuring announcements
Committee structures with overlapping authority
Leadership commentary about 'alignment challenges' or 'cross-functional coordination'
Evidence of escalation forums used to resolve routine decisions
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Clear accountability for end-to-end outcomes in single roles
Rapid decision cycles with minimal escalation
Successful execution of cross-functional initiatives at scale
Org structure with unified P&L accountability
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Analyze disclosed initiative timelines, committee charters, decision escalation paths, and leadership commentary on decision-making speed

hypotheses.hypothesis: Execution degrades at handoff points between sales-delivery, delivery-support, or product-engineering due to misaligned incentives or accountability gaps
supporting_evidence_sources: Customer complaints about post-sales execution or support quality
NPS or CSAT decline patterns tied to specific handoff stages
Restructuring efforts focused on 'end-to-end ownership'
Disclosed SLA misses or delivery delays
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Consistent service quality metrics across customer lifecycle
Unified teams with end-to-end accountability
High NPS with no handoff-related complaint patterns
Evidence of seamless handoffs without rework
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Map process flows from disclosed descriptions, analyze customer complaint patterns, review SLA/KPI performance, examine reorg rationale for handoff fixes

hypotheses.hypothesis: Geographic delivery fragmentation creates time-zone coordination delays, single points of failure, or geopolitical execution risk
supporting_evidence_sources: Disclosed delivery locations with critical functions concentrated in single regions
Incident response or escalation delays attributed to time-zone coverage gaps
Outsourcing or offshoring disclosures without redundancy evidence
Geopolitical risk disclosures (labor disputes, regulatory changes, sanctions)
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Follow-the-sun delivery model with documented redundancy
Multi-region delivery with no critical single points of failure
Evidence of seamless global coordination
No disclosed geopolitical or labor disruptions affecting operations
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Map disclosed delivery locations against critical function requirements, analyze incident response capabilities, review geopolitical risk factors

hypotheses.hypothesis: Sales or operational incentives reward short-term outcomes that create long-term execution problems, margin erosion, or customer churn
supporting_evidence_sources: Sales compensation heavily weighted to bookings vs. renewal or profitability
Evidence of deal discounting pressure or margin erosion post-sale
Customer churn patterns tied to overselling or misaligned expectations
Disclosed incentive structures misaligned with stated strategic priorities
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Compensation tied to customer lifetime value, retention, or profitability
Stable margins without post-sale erosion
High renewal rates with no overselling evidence
Aligned incentives across sales, delivery, and support
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Analyze disclosed compensation structures, margin trends post-sale, churn patterns, customer complaint themes, sales cycle vs. delivery execution gaps

hypotheses.hypothesis: Operating model cannot scale without degradationâ€”historical growth periods correlate with service quality decline, margin pressure, or operational chaos
supporting_evidence_sources: Historical periods of rapid growth followed by quality metric declines
Restructuring or 'focus' initiatives after expansion attempts
Disclosed capacity constraints or delivery delays during growth
Leadership commentary about 'stabilization' or 'operational rigor' post-growth
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Consistent quality metrics during historical growth periods
Evidence of scalable processes without heroics
No restructuring or 'focus' initiatives post-growth
Margin expansion with volume growth
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Correlate revenue growth periods with service quality metrics, margin trends, restructuring timing, and leadership commentary on operational challenges

hypotheses.hypothesis: Operating model contains unresolved contradictions (centralized/decentralized, cost/quality, speed/control) that persist through workarounds and leadership intervention
supporting_evidence_sources: Evidence of centralization/decentralization oscillation in restructuring history
Leadership commentary about balancing conflicting priorities
Disclosed efficiency initiatives followed by quality problems
Matrix structures or dual reporting without clear accountability
disconfirming_evidence_sources: Stable operating model without structural reorganizations
Clear authority and accountability without matrix ambiguity
No disclosed tradeoffs between speed, cost, and quality
Consistent execution without contradictory mandates
hypotheses.falsification_approach: Analyze restructuring frequency and rationale, leadership commentary on organizational tension, evidence of conflicting mandates or competing priorities
